section.title: Interest Rate Risk with Portfolios
section.p: Investors often hold portfolios of investments. This is just a collection of different investments. Now that we have examined interest rate for a single investment, we can use weighted averages to examine interest rate risk across a portfolio. Using weighted averages to extend a measure from a single investment to a portfolio will come up in Exam IFM as well.

introduction.p: Suppose an investor has a portfolio X consisting of investments (or just cash flows) of X_1, \ldots, X_n.

task.p: Both the Macaulay duration of the portfolio D_X and the modified duration of the portfolio MD_X are weighted averages of the durations D_i and MD_i respectively. The weights are the ratios of the present value of each investment to the present value of the entire portfolio.
Write a formula for the weight \omega_i and show that \sum \omega_i = 1.
Write formulas for D_X and MD_X. You can use the expression \omega_i for the weights to keep things relatively clean.

A portfolio contains 30,000 worth of bonds with modified duration MD = 3.96; 20,000 worth of bonds with modified duration MD = 4.08; 40,000 worth of bonds with modified duration MD = 1.69; and 10,000 worth of zero-coupon bonds with a term of 10 years that are priced to yield 7%. Find the modified duration of the portfolio.
You have purchased three bonds to form a portfolio as follows:

li.p: Bond A has semiannual coupons at 4%, a Macaulay duration of 21.46 years, and was purchased for 980.
Bond B is a 15-year bond with a Macaulay duration of 12.35 years and was purchased for 1015.
Bond C has a Macaulay duration of 16.67 years and was purchased for 1000.

task.p: Calculate the Macaulay duration of the portfolio at the time of purchase.

introduction.p: As with other concepts, sometimes the information you are given or have to find can vary. Solve the following problems in which this is the case.

task.p: A portfolio contains 20,000 worth of bonds with duration D = 5.46; 40,000 worth of bonds with modified duration MD = 6.71 priced to yield 5%; and 20,000 worth of bonds with duration D = 9.1. Find the Macaulay duration of the portfolio.

An investor has a portfolio containing 3,000 worth of a four year bond with a modified duration of 3.6, 6,000 worth of a five year bond with a modified duration of X, and 7,000 worth of a six year bond with a modified duration of 5.8. If the modified duration of the entire portfolio is 5, calculate X.

statement.p: If we want to use "chunking" to find the duration of an annuity in which the interest rate or the payment changes, we have to treat it as a portfolio. For the following problem, recall that if we have an annuity with Macaulay duration D, if we defer that annuity by n payments, the Macaulay duration of the deferred annuity is D' = n + D.

Suppose David Lee Roth has an annuity-immediate with ten annual payments of 1,200 followed by fifteen annual payments of 1900. The annuities are valued with an effective annual interest rate \iota = 6.5\%.
Calculate the Macaulay duration and the modified duration of this annuity by treating the annuity as a portfolio with an annuity at one payment level and a deferred annuity at another payment level.

introduction.p: We can use Macaulay or modified duration to estimate the change in price of a portfolio. You might have different values of \Delta \iota for each investment. If you are using a yield curve, you might have different values of \Delta \iota for each spot rate. If the spot rates in a yield curve all have the same change, this is called a parallel shift in the yield curve.

Bond A has annual coupons at a rate of 5% for 3 years, and Bond B is a three-year zero coupon bond. A portfolio X contains 30,000 worth of Bond A and 20,000 worth of Bond B.

task.p: Find the Macaulay duration of the portfolio X.
Find the modified duration of the portfolio X. For each of the bonds, use the flat effective annual yield rate that results in the prices you found above.
Use the modified duration to estimate the first order change in the value of X for a parallel shift in the yield curve of \Delta \iota = -0.01.
